;马来西亚向新加坡出口数十亿美元可再生能源的愿望绝不能削弱首先专家警告说，要使其国内经济重新站稳脚跟。

;

;本月早些时候，安瓦尔·易卜拉欣总理的政府重新启动了该国的可再生能源 (RE) 政策，解除了对可再生能源出口的禁令以支付国家雄心勃勃的能源目标。

;

;政府估计在未来三十年内需要超过 6300 亿林吉特（1384 亿美元）才能将可再生能源的份额提高到其总电力的 70%发电，目前以煤炭和天然气为主。

;

;绿色氢：马来西亚的清洁能源救星还是“危险的分心”？

;

;但由于国债高企、基础设施有限和政府认为，胆怯的本地投资者增加可再生能源出口——主要是出口到新加坡——是为其自身能源转型提供资金的合乎逻辑的方式。

;

;“将马来西亚产生的可再生能源出售给新加坡的吸引力很明显：新加坡的人均 GDP 收入更高，其强势货币提高了投资回报率。即便如此，这一战略还是有缺陷的，”东南亚气候行动网络 (Cansea) 区域协调员 Nithi Nesadurai 说。

;

;政府应优先考虑国内可再生能源电力的消费，这反过来会导致Nithi 补充说，由于相对于化石燃料的成本优势，可以降低关税。

;

;“如果马来西亚无法在本地核算和清点自己的可再生能源电力，那将是具有讽刺意味的，因为它是由新加坡进口的，”他说。

;

;新加坡在去年 6 月至 10 月期间通过老挝人民民主共和国-泰国-马来西亚-新加坡电力整合项目购买了老挝水坝产生的 170,000 兆瓦电力。这足以为新加坡约 452,000 套组屋提供一个月的电力。

;

;在本月早些时候举行的东盟峰会期间，新加坡总理李显龙呼吁成员国推动区域性以加强能源安全和弹性并推进区域脱碳。

;

;但是，对可靠的可再生能源不断增长的需求让老挝付出了代价，老挝牺牲了生态保护来建造 70 座水坝——至少至少还有几个正在筹备中——在寻求成为“亚洲电池”的过程中。

;

;老挝成为“亚洲电池”的努力会导致它失去联合国教科文组织的遗址吗？

;

;马来西亚战略与国际研究所 (ISIS-Malaysia) 高级分析师 Ahmad Afandi 表示，如果管理不当，可再生能源基础设施的快速扩张可能会给马来西亚带来一系列新问题。

; p>;Ahmad 表示，政府需要制定一项全面而全面的计划，以指导该行业确保其自始至终遵守全球环境可持续性标准，避免以牺牲环境和当地社区为代价。

;

;“这是政府对该行业的发展进行高度监管很重要，而不仅仅是将其留给自由市场，”他说。

;

;随着马来西亚 TNB 寻求替代品，对印度尼西亚煤炭价差的担忧

;

;根据国际可再生​​能源署 (Irena) 的最新数据，马来西亚仍然严重依赖煤炭和天然气为家庭和工业供电，可再生能源仅占总发电量的 16%，主要来自水力发电。

;

;2021 年太阳能装机容量为 1,780 兆瓦，不到水电装机容量 6,211 兆瓦的三分之一。

;

;然而，该国的能源转型将取决于利用其丰富的阳光。< /p>;

;Irena 预计，到 2050 年，太阳能光伏装置的装机容量将增至 153 吉瓦。该机构表示，这可能会使可再生能源占马来西亚能源结构的 89%。

;

;

;

;马来西亚表示，今年将投资 5000 万林吉特，在政府大楼和设施中安装屋顶太阳能基础设施。

;

;治理和政治研究中心的气候变化顾问 Renard Siew 说马来西亚决定允许向新加坡出售可再生能源是“朝着正确方向迈出的一步”，这将鼓励在马来西亚进行更多投资和创造“绿色”就业机会。

;

;“这也有助于促进更紧密的合作Siew 说。

;

;但说服潜在的企业合作伙伴投资昂贵的大型太阳能设施以最终将可再生能源出售给新加坡需要的不仅仅是崇高的鼓舞人心的演讲，专家警告说。< /p>;

;“安装（太阳能基础设施）是一回事，使其成为马来西亚文化又是另一回事，”政府事务咨询公司 Vriens & Partners 的高级分析师 Halmie Azrie 说。

;

;他补充说，政府有责任为任何考虑向该行业注入资金的大公司提供监管支持和培训大量本地人才。

;

;“做出这些预测是为了让投资者和政府参与进来正在提供乐观的叙述，因为他们相信支持将会到来，”他说。 “这是否会成功还有待观察。跨国公司需要带头，但这需要进行大量讨论，而且所有这些都需要时间。”

;

;

;

;在马来西亚经济繁荣时期养活该行业1980 年代到 1990 年代，前几届政府与企业巨头达成交易，创建独立发电厂 (IPP)，这些发电厂建造和维护以煤炭和天然气为燃料的发电厂。

;

;IPP 是在不透明的条款下成立的，这些条款仍然存在根据《官方保密法》被封锁。

;

;公开的事实是，他们几十年来一直受益于政府对天然气的广泛补贴，批评人士称，这使 IPP 所有者能够大赚一笔

;

;自 2010 年以来，政府逐渐取消了这些补贴。

;

;大流行后马来西亚的可持续旅游会蓬勃发展吗？

;

;但是政府吸引企业资金以加快其能源转型的计划提醒人们，与大企业过于紧密合作的风险。

;

;“可再生能源的真正潜力在于其分散化的能力Cansea 的 Nithi 说，“这样社区和公众就能够首先生产和使用电力。”

;

;“然后他们出口任何盈余或进口赤字。这减少了我们目前依赖大公司的需要。”

;

;ISIS-Malaysia 的 Ahmad 表示，政府可以考虑基于市场的气候变化工具，例如碳定价，为该国的气候变化提供资金。能源转型，而不是退回到私有化的旧战略。

;

;“总的来说，马来西亚的可再生能源转型融资需要在更大、更全面的绿色融资框架下采取胡萝卜加大棒的方法，”他说。

;一个强壮的裸照男子在台湾一家便利店内失控的在线视频吸引了人们的注意社交媒体。

;

;5 月 21 日，这段戏剧性的片段在台湾和香港的网上广为流传，视频显示一名光着膀子的肌肉男在 7-11 便利店内愤怒地尖叫。

; p>;

;据台湾媒体报道，这名男子姓朱，是一名28岁的健身教练和健美运动员。

;

;他愤怒的一个原因是他最喜欢的意大利黑人胡椒味鸡胸肉卖完了。

;

;一位自称在现场的网络观察员说，朱某得知自己最喜欢的菜卖完后很沮丧，开始责骂店员。

;

; p>;

;然后朱某大发雷霆，开始在店内大喊大叫，然后将货架上的农产品扔到地上。

;

;此时，一名店员报了警。

;

;民警赶到现场，搜出四包香草味鸡胸肉，朱某却不服气，怒气冲冲地殴打民警。

;

;一名警察用警棍打他，使朱的上半身流血后，他被制服并被捕。

;

;网上的照片在台湾引发了警方是否反应过度的质疑。

;

;在香港，然而，网上观察家嘲笑朱的滑稽动作。

;

;一些人说这位健身教练看起来像台湾版的电视剧和电影角色“绿巨人”。其他人说他让他们想起了日本漫画系列龙珠中的角色“赛亚人”。

;

;另一个片段显示了第二个店员跑过满是碎片的商店，并试图阻止有人拍摄这一事件。< /p>;

;一位香港在线观察员批评该员工说：“他不关心商店。他关心其他人拍视频。”

;

;视频在网上疯传后，自称认识朱的人对他失控的原因给出了不同的解释。

;

;有人说朱“失控了” ” 在他“被抓到出轨女友”之后。

;

;另一位声称他在 5 月 20 日向女友求婚，这一天在普通话中听起来像“我爱你”，但被拒绝了。

;

;朱尚未对他的行为作出公开解释。

; Sun, 28 May 2023 09:20:02 +0800 Chinese app factory Newborn Town has designs on Southeast Asia with many smaller platforms, flipping the TikTok modelhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3221949/chinese-app-factory-newborn-town-has-designs-southeast-asia-many-smaller-platforms-flipping-tiktok?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.28 09:00;
;;

;Yumy、Mico 和 Yoho 在东南亚和中东地区。他们还有其他共同点：都是一个中国开发者。

;

;正如中国制造的商品是世界各地零售店的主要商品一样，中国在过去二十年的互联网服务繁荣创造了一个雄心勃勃的应用程序工厂大军，他们的应用程序在海外家喻户晓。尽管政治审查越来越严格，但像 Newborn Town 这样的中国开发商越来越多地证明他们有能力实现这一目标。

;

;与总部位于北京的字节跳动（主要以其广受欢迎的短视频应用程序 TikTok 而闻名）不同，Newborn 正在制作在将其许多较小的应用程序安装到智能手机上并嵌入到世界许多角落的用户生活方式方面取得了坚实的进展。在亚洲和中东取得初步成功后，该公司已开始关注更成熟的市场，如美国和日本，该公司联合创始人李平在北京办公室接受南华早报采访时表示。 5 月 11 日。

;

;李开始生产应用程序的业务的起步很卑微。 2011年，他从河北科技师范大学（一所以培养教师而著称的地区性大学）毕业后，最初为寻找理想工作而苦苦挣扎，当时他和许多有抱负的年轻人一样来到北京寻找更美好的未来。

;

;然而，这一举动以不同的方式证明是偶然的：李遇到了刘春和，刘春和正在寻找合作伙伴来帮助创业，当时似乎整个中国仍被控制

;

;“回想起来，我们开始新的业务可能只是因为他找不到人加入他的业务，而我也找不到工作，所以我们一拍即合”，李说。

;

;随着社交媒体和直播的兴起，这项投资证明是成功的。智能手机和宽带服务的普及永久性地改变了中国人与人之间的互动方式。腾讯控股于 2011 年推出了目前中国最大的社交媒体应用程序微信，成为中国在线生活的必备工具。在随后的几年里，许多其他社交和约会应用程序如雨后春笋般涌现。

;

;蒙大拿州成为美国第一个全面禁止 TikTok 的州

;

;这种繁荣为新生镇提供了它所需要的人才和经验专注于竞争相对较少的海外市场。自从成为 BlueCity Holdings 的大股东以来，该公司现在拥​​有许多社交媒体应用程序，包括同性恋约会应用程序 Blued。

;

;该公司的社交媒体应用程序平均每月有 2290 万活跃用户，据称其年度报告。它报告 2022 年的收入为 28 亿元人民币（3.958 亿美元），同比增长 18.6%。利润增长更快，去年增长 174.2% 至 2.873 亿元。

;

;2021 年，李克强从现任董事长的刘强东手中接过首席执行官一职。

;

;为了征服海外市场，该公司一直在开展许多本地化的营销活动。比如Mico去年就在泰国和越南推出了产品主题曲。其泰国歌曲“Tuk Krub”在 YouTube 上的播放量已达 1.2 亿次。据 Newborn 称，这也是当地主流音乐平台年度点击量最高的前五名歌曲。

;

;“当人们在自己的祖国创业时，很自然地会考虑国内市场，”李说。 “一开始我们也做了类似的事情，但是当我们看海外市场时……我们意识到中国以外的市场肯定是更大的市场。”

;

;“东南亚和中东提供China Skinny 董事总经理马克·坦纳 (Mark Tanner) 表示：“与其他市场相比，它们具有优势，因为它们发展迅速，以数字为中心，而且现在对于希望在全球扩张的企业来说非常‘热门’。”

;

;地缘政治风险也很大根据 Tanner 的说法，该地区的国家“通常与北京的关系更好和/或经济风险更大”。

;

;去年，Newborn 扩展到 LGBTQ 社交网络。新生小镇出资成立的基金Metaclass Management ELP参与了BlueCity的私有化。根据 3 月宣布的新收购协议，Newborn 成为公司的控股股东。

;

;“我们的董事长与 BlueCity 的创始人有联系，当我们谈到 [收购] 时，我们一拍即合，”李说。 “我们正在寻求社交媒体板块的拓展，从用户的真实需求出发，也与蓝城的原班人马达成了共识。所以这个过程用了不到一年的时间，而且相对较快。”

;

;“正如你想象的那样，LGBTQ 人群在现实中寻找伴侣的效率可能非常低，”李补充道。 “但如果他们通过社交媒体平台来做，效率可以大大提高，并会逐渐形成自己的社区氛围。”

;

;近年来，中国互联网公司积极寻求海外增长，国内增长放缓，全球市场也面临一些挫折。 TikTok 在拥有 1.5 亿活跃用户的美国面临着巨大的压力，因为政府威胁要禁止或强制出售。

;

;中国企业现在在海外扩张中面临越来越大的风险和复杂性，据称贝恩公司今年早些时候发布的一份报告。

;

;贝恩合伙人朱立强告诫企业在地缘政治风险方面要有“正确的预期”。 “我们不想呈现和平与繁荣的虚假画面，”他说。 “地缘政治问题正变得越来越明显……尤其是在明年举行美国总统大选等重大事件时。”

;

;李认为海外扩张最重要的因素是遵守当地法规。 “当你考虑一种商业模式时，你必须遵守 Apple 的 App Store 和 Google Play 的规则以及我们业务所在的每个市场的政策，”他说。

;

;回顾他的整个旅程，李说困难一直存在。 “我不得不承认，当然，我们失败了很多次。有时事情会卡住。它有很多曲折，”他说。 “如果我们做对了一切，也许我们现在会更有信心。”

; Sun, 28 May 2023 09:20:02 +0800 Number of Hong Kong students at Britain’s independent schools surges nearly fivefold in 2 yearshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3222023/number-hong-kong-students-britains-independent-schools-surges-nearly-fivefold-2-years?utm_source=rss_feed

;英国私立独立学校的香港学生人数猛增近五倍两年，因为富裕的父母选择为孩子的教育支付更多费用。

;

;根据英国独立学校委员会上周的一份报告，2,357 名来自香港的学生中至少有一位父母居住在英国就读私立学校的人数高于去年的 1,538 人和 2021 年的 496 人。

;

;父母居住在海外的私立学校的香港学生人数增加了近 5,654 人。

;

;香港人是最大的群体连续第二年就读私立学校的海外学生，其次是中国内地和德国。

;

;私立学校收取高昂的学费，相比之下，大多数香港儿童就读于英国的免费公费校园.

;

;2020 年北京在香港实施国家安全法后，根据英国国家海外签证计划，约有 41,000 名 18 岁以下香港人获得移民签证。

;

;评论急剧上升该委员会在其报告中表示：“鉴于政府允许香港英国国民（海外）在英国重新定居的政策发生变化，这并不令人意外。”

;

;更多从 2021 年到去年，超过 160,000 名香港人申请了移民途径，该途径允许成功的申请人及其家属在英国生活、工作和学习长达五年，之后他们可以申请公民身份。

;

;香港 BN(O) 持有人的 1,000 名成年子女关注扩大英国计划

;

;Britannia StudyLink 的创始人 Samuel Chan Sze-ming 是一家主要帮助学生进入英国私立学校的香港企业，最近成立

;

;他说，最初大多数移民的香港人都会把孩子送到免费的公立学校或公立文法学校。

;

;但一些较富裕的父母后来决定将他们的孩子转到私立学校，期望更好的设施和教学质量。

;

;Chan 说，私立学校的非寄宿学校每年的费用可能接近 8,000 英镑（77,000 港元）。

;

; p>;

;“他们可能会发现公立学校在教牧关怀方面不够好，可能存在欺凌和教师流失等问题，”他说。

;

;“一些文法学校非常好，牛津和剑桥等大学都喜欢录取学生，但只有大约 163 所文法学校，录取竞争激烈。”

;

;BN(O) 香港人暂留移民计划：英国外交官< /h3>;

;香港移民 Mandy Lai* 在他们根据 BN(O) 签证计划抵达英国后，将她 10 岁的女儿送到一所免费的公立学校。

;

;澳大利亚总理安东尼·艾博年在最近于日本举行的 G7 峰会上支持联合声明降低与中国的贸易风险，因为他的贸易部长 Don Farrell 结束了北京之行，寻求结束澳大利亚出口关税，因为该国对其最大的出口伙伴采取了姿态。

;

;堪培拉的这种矛盾的做法已经成为其与北京外交的标志。一方面，它伸出橄榄枝，寻求停止或缓和影响其出口的经济紧张局势。另一方面，它抓住干草叉，通过七国集团等外交论坛或四方安全对话和 Aukus 联盟等军事论坛表现出敌意。

;

;随着阿尔巴尼斯政府纪念其成立一周年，这种情况更加恶化。办公室。他对中国的战略被贴上了“重置”的标签，但它需要更透明地表明堪培拉想如何给中国贴上标签：是朋友还是敌人。

;

;政局动荡，外交部长黄英贤主张为了和平与合作。与此同时，在副总理理查德·马勒斯的领导下，国防部不断公布与美国合作的新军事举措，明确针对中国。

;

;在她访问北京期间为庆祝两国建交 50 周年，黄之锋说“冰融化，但速度很慢”。针对中国的军事姿态和联合声明可能会再次冻结关系。自第二次世界大战以来，澳大利亚的外交政策从未如此以军事为中心。这与澳大利亚实现其外交政策目标的核心几十年的外交冒险背道而驰。

;

;黄之锋的外交一直是澳大利亚与中国重新建立外交关系的基石。她的行为符合她的意图，以尊重的方式重新接触和稳定关系，反映了她的亚洲传统。

;

;作为她外交姿态的一部分，这种冷静的头脑以及礼貌和尊重的基本原则已经允许她在印度和印度尼西亚举行的 G20 会议期间向中国高级外交官王毅示好，这些会议去年打开了通往北京的大门。

;

;这可能会安排 Albanese 进行国事访问，以配合10 月，澳大利亚总理 (Gough Whitlam) 首次访华 50 周年。这些姿态表明，在堪培拉的大厅里，人们希望通过地缘经济的镜头而不是安全的棱镜来看待澳大利亚和中国。

;

;但其他人，政治家和智囊团之类的人，仍然持有强权的殖民心态他们想要威胁制裁，迫使区域合作伙伴对中国采取孤立主义战略，并说服他们与赠款和特殊条款的诱惑脱钩。

;

;这种骚动是由恐惧引发的中国在自己领海内的军事集结。澳大利亚正在建设其军事能力，以保卫其边界和海上交通线。

;

;如果中国——澳大利亚最大的进出口伙伴——真的想要造成伤害，北京将更容易简单地采取行动关闭与该国的贸易——它在 2020 年几乎这样做了——而不是进行军事接触。

;

;即使中美军事冲突在该地区爆发，北京的海上力量也会更多地关注第一和第二岛链，并且不太可能将其努力扩展到澳大利亚。堪培拉最新的战略防御评估承认了这一点，明确表示中国对其边境安全没有直接威胁。

;

;澳大利亚为什么在关系升温时挥舞着中国的“威胁”？

;

;由澳大利亚、加拿大、新西兰、英国和美国组成的“五眼联盟”情报网络最近发起了另一场妖魔化中国的战线。在《悉尼先驱晨报》的一篇文章中，他们指责北京对其他国家进行了系统性的秘密干涉和恐吓活动，但没有提供具体例子。这与 1990 年代抹黑萨达姆·侯赛因并为入侵伊拉克和阿富汗辩护的虚假宣传活动相呼应。

;

;联邦调查局副局长保罗·阿贝特在文章中的评论 – 他说中国“对美国构成严重威胁”我们每个国家、我们的生活方式、我们的民主制度和我们如此珍视的自由”——回到乔治·W·布什总统 2001 年关于恐怖分子的演讲。布什当时说：“他们讨厌我们的自由——我们的宗教自由、我们的言论自由、我们的投票和集会自由以及彼此不同意的自由。”

;

;这种旨在激发公众支持的言论是危险的，因为它将进一步分裂和制造中澳之间的不信任，并导致打击毒品等跨国努力的失败。

;

;澳大利亚必须走自己的道路与中国和解，而不是让第三方野心使它脱轨。堪培拉有两个课程：Wong 的课程基于建立信任和相互尊重，而 Marles 的课程旨在延续莫里森政府的政策——导致价值 200 亿澳元（150 亿美元）的澳大利亚商品受到制裁或

;

;北京已邀请 Albanese 今年晚些时候访问。他坚持认为必须在他出访前取消出口禁令。值得注意的是，中方从未要求澳方放弃军事强势作为会谈的先决条件。这是因为中国对澳大利亚的政策是明确的。

;

;但阿尔巴尼亚政府却很困惑——是要伸出橄榄枝来提振本国经济，还是为美国牺牲肢体来遏制中国在印太地区。

; Sun, 28 May 2023 07:50:02 +0800 US nuclear umbrella for Taiwan: solid cross-strait shield or wishful thinking?https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3222018/us-nuclear-umbrella-taiwan-solid-cross-strait-shield-or-wishful-thinking?utm_source=rss_feed

;As Washington and Beijing ramp up their military signalling on Taiwan, the self-ruled island has started to discuss what was once unthinkable – to come under the US nuclear umbrella that has successfully protected Japan, South Korea and Australia for decades.

;

;The debate was set off after Taiwanese Foreign Minister Joseph Wu suggested on Monday that the island had been in talks with the United States on the nuclear umbrella issue.

;

;Some local defence analysts argue that the island would be better off having such a shield, as extra security against any military assault from across the Taiwan Strait.

;

;But others say that seeking any such arrangement would be unrealistic, as it might require the US to adjust its decades-long “strategic ambiguity” on the issue of Taiwan. The island also has higher defence priorities like securing deals for advanced weapons, they say.

;

;Strategic ambiguity is a deliberately vague US stand on defending Taiwan should it face armed conflict with Beijing, which sees the island as a breakaway territory that must be reunified – by force if necessay.

;

;Pressed by a lawmaker on whether Taiwan had indeed sought US protection given Beijing's growing nuclear arsenal, Wu said: “Regarding the discussion of this issue with the United States, it is not suitable for me to make it public here.”

;

;G7 summit: China nuke build-up 'concern for global stability'

;

;The “nuclear umbrella” refers to a guarantee by a nuclear-armed state to defend a non-nuclear ally.

;

;While Wu declined to offer details on the US talks, he nonetheless emphasised that the nuclear umbrella issue was “very important”.

;

;As Taiwan maintained a policy of not developing, stockpiling or using nuclear weapons, it would not tolerate any threats of a nuclear strike, he said.

;

;“This is why we have communication with our good friends who have similar concerns about the issue,” Wu said, without identifying the parties involved.

;

;Japan, South Korea, Australia, New Zealand, and the Nato countries are covered by the US nuclear umbrella. Taiwan, whose 1980s research programme to secretly develop atomic weapons was stopped at Washington's behest, has long hoped to be included as well.

;

;On Tuesday, a Taiwanese foreign ministry spokesman also declined to give details of the umbrella issue, including when the discussions began and what the progress had been.

;

;“In the face of growing military threats from [mainland] China, it is our own duty to safeguard Taiwan … strengthen our defence capability and solidify our relations with like-minded countries and security partners … to ensure peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and Indo-Pacific region,” spokesman Jeff Liu said in Taipei.

;

;Military muscle-flexing by Beijing has spiked as Taiwan's independence-leaning government led by President Tsai Ing-wen has deepened its relationship with the West, the US in particular. The United States, like most countries, does not see Taiwan as a sovereign state but is opposed to any forcible change to the cross-strait status quo.

;

;The US' closer ties with Taiwan have also been fostered by Washington's spiralling rivalry with Beijing, especially over its rapid military expansion in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Some American lawmakers and think-tank experts have also proposed that Taiwan be placed under US protection.

;

;The 2020 Taiwan Defence Act introduced by Republicans Senator Josh Hawley and Representative Mike Gallagher called for US assessment of the use of nuclear force to help defend the island against any nuclear threats from Beijing.

;

;American political scientist John Mearscheimer, an international affairs professor at the University of Chicago, has also said that a nuclear umbrella would “create a powerful, conventional deterrent in Taiwan”.

;

;It would send a clear message to Beijing that “if they are to attack Taiwan, it will escalate to the nuclear level”, Mearscheimer told the Taipei-based CommonWealth Magazine in an interview in December.

;

;The White House has yet to express its stand on the issue.

;

;Analysts in Taiwan said that since neighbours Japan and South Korea were covered by Washington's Extended Deterrence Strategy – which included the nuclear umbrella – adding Taipei would create a stronger deterrent effect for Beijing.

;

;Taiwan's own choice to remain non-nuclear would also help it draw military support, according to Su Tzu-yun, senior analyst at the Institute for National Defence and Security Research, a government think tank in New Taipei.

;

;“Taiwan has maintained a policy of not developing nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, and therefore, other like-minded countries would be more willing to support Taiwan if it faced nuclear threats,” Su said.

;

;“If Taiwan is included, it would provide Taiwan an extended form of deterrence that would greatly enhance its security.”

;

;Beijing would then be more cautious in planning any attack on the island, nuclear or otherwise, Su added.

;

;Wang Kung-yi, director of the Taiwan International Strategic Study Society, a Taipei think tank, said the West was increasingly concerned about Beijing's military pressure campaign against Taiwan.

;

;“If Taiwan is not able to come under US nuclear protection, a possible way is for the US to send nuclear submarines through the waters close to the Taiwan Strait as a kind of deterrence,” Wang said.

;

;Taiwan's high-level exchanges with US officials in particular have triggered unprecedented People's Liberation Army warplane sorties, extended live-fire drills, as well as simulated precision strikes and blockades around the island in recent months.

;

;Chang Yen-ting, a retired Taiwanese lieutenant general, said Taiwan was the central pivot of the so-called first island chain line of defence off the East Asian continental coast, and strategically important for the US to retain its influence in the western Pacific.

;

;“It would help to undermine the Chinese communists' efforts to extend their forces to the western Pacific if Taiwan was under the nuclear umbrella,” Chang said.

;

;'This is the fate of Taiwan': island stays on guard as superpowers square up

;

;But Chang also sought to allay nuclear assault concerns, given how close Taiwan sat to mainland China. “It is unlikely for Beijing to use nuclear weapons to attack Taiwan, given the radiation spillover problem and the proximity of Taiwan to the Chinese mainland,” he said.

;

;According to Chang, what Taiwan needs most is to acquire more advanced US military hardware, like F-35 fighter jets, P-8 anti-submarine aircraft and other weapons, to counter Beijing's latest lines of weapons, like the emerging J-31 fifth-generation stealth fighter.

;

;“Taiwan's priority should be to get more advanced and effective weapons instead of seeking to be incorporated into the nuclear umbrella,” he said.

;

;Chieh Chung, a security analyst at the National Policy Foundation, a think tank affiliated with Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang party, said becoming one of the US' nuclear umbrella allies might be wishful thinking for Taiwan.

;

;“Taiwan and the US do not have a mutual defence agreement and those under the umbrella are allies Washington has committed to defend in line with their mutual defence treaties,” Cheih said.

;

;Moreover, even with such defence agreements, the US had not totally committed to using nuclear weapons to defend allies from nuclear attacks, he noted.

;

;“Take South Korea, for example,” Chieh said. “The two sides have had a mutual defence treaty for close to 70 years but, until today, the US has not entirely committed to using nuclear weapons to help defend South Korea in the event of a nuclear attack from North Korea.”

;

;While the US was concerned about the risk of a potential cross-strait war, it continued to maintain a policy of strategic ambiguity on the issue, Chieh noted.

;

;“This is because Washington is worried that if it changes its strategic ambiguity policy into strategic clarity, it could offer a blank cheque to [Taiwan's] pro-independence supporters who could be encouraged to breach Beijing's red line, resulting in the Chinese communists sending forces to attack Taiwan.”

;

;The US policy of strategic ambiguity, which neither commits to nor rules out military action to defend Taiwan, is designed to leave Beijing guessing about the likely American response to any attack on the island.

;

;The policy also keeps the pro-independence camp in Taiwan from pursuing its cause – a move that Beijing has vowed would provoke an attack.

;

;Chieh said if the US had no desire to adjust this policy, it would be less likely to talk to Taiwan about the nuclear umbrella.

;

;Li Da-jung, a professor of international relations and strategic studies at Tamkang University in New Taipei, said the Tsai government must remain prudent in dealing with such a sensitive issue.

;

;“A nuclear umbrella for Taiwan is certain to sharply provoke Beijing which is expected to respond with actions even more violently than after the [Nancy] Pelosi visit, given that it would cross the mainland's bottom line,” Li said.

;

;The PLA staged a series of unprecedented live-fire drills around the island in August after then-US House speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taiwan in defiance of repeated warnings from Beijing, which saw the trip as a violation of its sovereignty.

;Turks vote on Sunday in a presidential run-off that could see Recep Tayyip Erdogan extend his rule into a third decade and intensify Turkey's increasingly authoritarian path, muscular foreign policy and unorthodox economic governance.

;

;Erdogan, 69, defied opinion polls and came out comfortably ahead with an almost five-point lead over his rival Kemal Kilicdaroglu in the first round on May 14. But he fell just short of the 50 per cent needed to avoid a run-off, in a race with profound consequences for Turkey itself and global geopolitics.

;

;His unexpectedly strong showing amid a deep cost of living crisis, and a win in parliamentary elections for a coalition of his conservative Islamist-rooted AK Party (AKP), the nationalist MHP and others, buoyed the veteran campaigner who says a vote for him is a vote for stability.

;

;Kilicdaroglu, 74, is the candidate of a six-party opposition alliance, and leads the Republican People's Party (CHP) created by Turkey's founder Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. His camp has struggled to regain momentum after the shock of trailing Erdogan in the first round.

;

;The election will decide not only who leads Turkey, a Nato-member country of 85 million, but also how it is governed, where its economy is headed after its currency plunged to one tenth of its value against the dollar in a decade, and the shape of its foreign policy, which has seen Turkey irk the West by cultivating ties with Russia and Gulf states.

;

;The initial election showed larger-than-expected support for nationalism – a powerful force in Turkish politics which has been hardened by years of hostilities with Kurdish militants, an attempted coup in 2016 and the influx of millions of refugees from Syria since war began there in 2011.

;

;Turkey is the world's largest host of refugees, with some 5 million migrants, of whom 3.3 million are Syrians, according to Interior Ministry data.

;

;Turkey's Erdogan wins support of eliminated, third-place rival in run-off

;

;Third-place presidential candidate and hardline nationalist Sinan Ogan said he endorsed Erdogan based on a principle of “non-stop struggle (against) terrorism”, referring to pro-Kurdish groups. He achieved 5.17 per cent of the vote.

;

;Another nationalist, Umit Ozdag, leader of the anti-immigrant Victory Party (ZP), announced a deal declaring ZP's support for Kilicdaroglu, after he said he would repatriate immigrants. The ZP won 2.2 per cent of votes in this month's parliamentary election.

;

;A closely-watched survey by pollster Konda for the run-off put support for Erdogan on 52.7 per cent and Kilicdaroglu on 47.3 per cent after distributing undecided voters. The survey was carried out on May 20-21, before Ogan and Ozdag revealed their endorsements.

;

;Another key is how Turkey's Kurds, at about a fifth of the population, will vote.

;

;The pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) party endorsed Kilicdaroglu in the first round but, after his lurch to the right to win nationalist votes, it did not explicitly name him and urged voters rather to reject Erdogan's “one-man regime” in the run-off.

;

;Polls will open at 8am local time and close at 5pm. By late on Sunday there should be a clear indication of the winner.

;Best actor went to the renowned Koji Yakusho, who plays a toilet cleaner in Tokyo in director Wim Wenders' Perfect Days.

;

;His award was accepted by the two main stars of the tragicomedy that follows a budding romance on his behalf.

;

;French-Vietnamese director Tran Anh Hung took home best director for The Pot-au-Feu, a food-obsessed French film starring Juliette Binoche and Benoit Magimel as a couple.

;While introducing best screenplay, actor John C Reilly showed his support for striking Hollywood writers with roughly a minute of wordless mimicry before saying: “What we just experienced is what a movie would be like without screenwriters.”

;That prize went to Yuji Sakamoto for the Japanese entry Monster, directed by Kore-eda, which follows a series of misunderstandings surrounding two schoolboys' friendship.

;This year's closing film is Pixar's Elemental, an animated feature about a city where the four elements live together, featuring the voices of Leah Lewis and Mamoudou Athie.
